blocks.text: Security control selection involves choosing appropriate technical, administrative, and physical controls to mitigate identified risks. At the infrastructure level, controls must scale, integrate with existing systems, and support centralized management.

Control selection begins with risk assessment. Organizations evaluate threat likelihood, vulnerability exposure, and business impact to determine where controls will provide the greatest benefit. High-value assets and externally exposed systems typically receive stronger protections.

Infrastructure controls include firewalls, intrusion detection systems, network access controls, authentication services, and logging platforms. Each control addresses specific threat scenarios and must be configured to align with organizational policies.

Interoperability is an important consideration. Controls that cannot share telemetry or integrate with monitoring systems reduce overall visibility. Security architecture increasingly favors platforms that support centralized analysis and automation.
Finally, control effectiveness must be validated through testing, audits, and incident simulations. Controls that exist on paper but are misconfigured or unmonitored provide little real protection.
